t: Her fetters shall be unto thee a strong defence, and her chains a robe of glory.
For her yoke is a golden ornament, and her bands are a riband of blue.
Thou shalt put her on, as a robe of honour, and shalt embrace her, as a crown of joy.
My son, if thou wilt, thou shalt be taught: and if thou apply thy mind, thou shalt be well versed.
If thou love to hear, thou shalt receive understanding: and if thou bow down thy ear, thou shalt be wise.
Stand in the multitude of the elders, and cleave unto him that is wise.
Willingly hear every godly discourse: and let not the parables of understanding escape thee.
And if thou see a man of understanding, get thee betimes unto him, and let thy foot wear the steps of his door.
Let thy mind be upon the ordinances of the Lord and meditate continually on his commandments: and he will establish thine heart, and give thee wisdom at thine own desire.
Do no evil, so shall no harm come unto thee.
Depart from the unjust, and iniquity shall depart from thee.
My son, sow not upon the furrows of unrighteousness, and thou shalt not reap them sevenfold.
Ask not of the Lord preeminence, neither of the king the seat of honour.
Justify not thyself before the Lord; and boast not of thy wisdom before the king.
Seek not to be judge, being not able to take away iniquity; lest at any time thou fear the person of the mighty, and lay a stumblingblock in the way of thy uprightness.
Offend not against the multitude of a city, neither cast thyself down among the people.
Bind not one sin upon another; for in one thou shalt not be unpunished.
Say not, God will look upon the multitude of my oblations, and when I offer to the most High God, he will accept it.
Be not fainthearted when thou makest thy prayer, and neglect not to give alms.
Laugh no man to scorn in the bitterness of his soul: for there is one which humbleth and lifteth up.
Devise not a lie against thy brother: neither do the like to thy friend.
Be not willing to utter any manner of lie: for the custom thereof is not good.
Use not many words in a multitude of elders, and make not much babbling when thou prayest.
Hate not laborious work, neither husbandry, which the most High hath ordained.
Number not thyself among the multitude of sinners, but remember that wrath will not tarry long.
Humble thy soul greatly: for the vengeance of the ungodly is fire and worms.
Change not a friend for any good by no means; neither a faithful brother for the gold of Ophir.
Forego not a wise and good woman: for her grace is above gold.
Oppress not an hireling that is true in his work, neither defraud him of his wages.
Love thy friend as thine own soul, and be mindful of him in thy heart.
Use no deceitful dealing against those that are subject to thee.
If thou have cattle, have an eye to them: and if they be profitable, keep them with thee.
If thou have children, instruct them, and bow down their neck from their youth.
If thou have daughters, have a care of their body, and shew not thyself cheerful toward them.
Marry thy daughter, and so shalt thou have performed a weighty matter: but give her to a man of understanding.
If thou have a wife that pleaseth thee well, forsake her not: but give not thyself over to her that thou hatest.
Honour thy father with thy whole heart, and forget not the sorrows of thy mother.
Remember that thou wast begotten of them; and how canst thou recompense them the things that they have done for thee?
Fear the Lord with all thy soul, and reverence his priests.
Love him that made thee with all thy strength, and forsake not his ministers.
Honour the Lord with all thy substance, and with the firstfruits of all thine increase:
That thy barns may be filled with plenty, and that thy presses may overflow with new wine.
Pour out thy soul above the dead, as going to suffer with them.
Be not slow to visit the sick: for that shall make thee to be beloved.
Remember thy end, and let enmity cease; [for corruption and death shall come upon thee,] and abide in the commandments.
Strive not with a man that is full of tongue, and heap not wood upon his fire.
Jest not with a rude man, lest thy ancestors be dishonoured.
Reproach not a man that turneth from sin, but remember that we are all worthy of punishment.
Dishonour not an old man; for even some of us wax old.
Rejoice not over thy greatest enemy being dead, but remember that we die all.
Despise not the discourse of the wise, but acquaint thyself with their proverbs: for of them thou shalt learn instruction, and how to serve great men with ease.
Miss not the discourse of the elders: for they also learned of their fathers, and of them thou shalt learn understanding, and to give answer as need requireth.
Enkindle not the coals of a sinner, lest thou be burned with the flame of his fire.
Stand not against the face of an impudent man, lest he rob thee of thy honour.
Get not a name of being a liar in no wise; and use not thyself to lying: for the custom thereof is naught.
Be not much given to babbling, but be slow to answer.
If thou understand an matter, answer thy neighbour; if not, lay thine hand upon thy mouth.
Honour and shame is in talk: and the tongue of man is his fall.
Be not called a whisperer, and be not in wait with thy tongue: for there is no shame upon a thief as upon an evil tongue:
For a lie is a foul blot in a man, and an unpleasing thing in the sight of God.
Be not hasty in thy spirit to be angry: for anger resteth in the bosom of fools.
Be in peace with many: nevertheless have but one counsellor of a thousand.
If thou wouldest get a friend, prove him first, and be not hasty to credit him.
For some man is a friend for his own occasion, and will not abide in the day of thy trouble.
Be not jealous over the wife of thy bosom, and teach her not an evil lesson against thyself.
Give not thy soul unto a woman to set her foot upon thy substance.
Meet not with an harlot, lest thou fall into her snares.
Use not much the company of a woman that is a singer, lest thou be taken with her attempts.
Gaze not on a maid, that thou fall not by those things that are beautiful.
Give not thy soul unto harlots, that thou lose not thine inheritance.
Look not round about thee in the streets of the city, neither wander thou in the solitary places thereof.
Turn away thine eye from a beautiful woman, and look not upon another's beauty; for beauty hath destroyed many, and therewith love is enkindled as a fire.

Sit not at all with another man's wife, nor sit down with her in thine arms, and spend not thy money with her at the wine; lest thine heart incline unto her, and so through thy desire thou fall into destruction.
Forsake not an old friend; for the new is not comparable to him: a new friend is as new wine; when it is old, thou shalt drink it with pleasure.
Envy not the honour of a sinner; for thou knowest not what shall be his end.
Delight not in the thing that the ungodly have pleasure in; but remember that they shall not go unpunished unto the grave.

Keep thee far from the man that hath power to kill; so shalt thou not doubt the fear of death: and if thou come unto him, offend not, lest he take away thy life: know thou that thou goest in the midst of snares, and that thou walkest upon the battlements of the city.
As near as thou canst, guess at thy neighbour, and consult with the wise.
Let thy talk be with the wise, and all thy communication in the law of the most High.
And let just men eat with thee; and let thy glorying be in the fear of the Lord.
The handiwork of an artisan is deserving of praise, but the ruler of the people should be wise in speech.
A fair speaker is feared in the city, and a babbler is hated.
A wise governor keeps his people in discipline, and the authority of a sensible man is well established.
As the governor is, so are his subordinates; as the ruler of the city, so are its inhabitants.
A king without instruction is the ruin of his people; a city owes its prosperity to the intelligence of its leaders.
In the hands of the Lord is the government of the world; in due season He raises up the leader who is fitting.
A man's success is in the hand of the Lord; it is He who gives glory to the scribe.
Bear not malice toward thy neighbor, whatever his offenses, and never react with acts of arrogance.
Pride is displeasing to God as well as to man, and both regard injustice as a fault.
Sovereignty passes from one nation to another because of injustice, arrogance, and money. Nothing is more impious than he who loves money: even his soul he will sell!
Why so much pride for one who is earth and ashes, a being who, living, already has loathsome entrails?
A long illness mocks the physician, who is king today, tomorrow shall die.
When a man dies, he receives as his portion the insects, the wild beasts, and the worms.
The beginning of human pride is to forsake the Lord and to keep one's heart far from the Creator.
For the beginning of pride is sin, and he who gives himself to it spreads abomination. Therefore, the Lord has made their distress conspicuous and has brought them to naught.
The Lord has overturned the throne of the mighty and seated the gentle in their place.
The Lord has uprooted the proud and planted the humble in their place.
The Lord has disrupted the territory of the nations and has annihilated them to the foundations of the earth.
He has sometimes taken them away and destroyed them and has erased their memory from the world.
Pride is not fitting for man, nor violent anger for the race of woman.
